channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Drones Changed This Civil War, and Linked Rebels to the World
item.description: Consumer technologies are altering the course of the battle in Myanmar, and rebel drone units are taking notes on Ukraine and other conflicts.

item.title: After 3 Tourists Go Missing, Bodies Are Found in Baja California
item.description: Mexican authorities recovered the three bodies as a search went on for two Australian tourists and a U.S. citizen who disappeared while on vacation.

item.title: London's Royal Opera House plans a new renaissance starting with a name change — and potential Netflix series
item.description: To fill a multimillion-pound funding gap, the institution will begin streaming on social media sites such as YouTube and will team up with brands.

item.title: Israel, Gaza and the Law on Starvation in War
item.description: A complex legal question became more pressing after a statement from the U.N. human rights chief.

item.title: Drones Changed This Civil War, and Linked Rebels to the World
item.description: Consumer technologies are altering the course of the battle in Myanmar, and rebel drone units are taking notes on Ukraine and other conflicts.

item.title: Europe’s largest smart city arises from the ashes of Greece’s debt crisis
item.description: Spread across 6,200 acres outside of Athens, Greece, Ellinikon will transform the coastline and the country.

item.title: Body Cameras Show NYPD Fatally Shooting Win Rozario, Man Who Was Holding Scissors
item.description: The man, Win Rozario, 19, had called 911 and seemed to be in mental distress, officials and his family said. The police appeared to shoot him at least four times.

item.title: Israel, Gaza and the Law on Starvation in War
item.description: A complex legal question became more pressing after a statement from the U.N. human rights chief.

item.title: The U.K. economy could stare down long-term irrelevance without immigration
item.description: The U.K. is expected to grow more slowly than most of the world's developed nations this year, but it can save itself in the long run.

item.title: C.J. Sansom, Mystery Novelist Drawn to Tudor England, Dies at 71
item.description: He wrote a popular series of books revolving around a hunchbacked detective, Shardlake, whose troubles echo the author’s experiences of childhood bullying.

item.title: Noisy, Gaudy and Spiritual: Young Pilgrims Embrace an Ancient Goddess
item.description: On an island whose religious diversity is part of its democratic identity, many of the faithful participating in a pilgrimage for Mazu, Goddess of the Sea, were in their 20s and teens.

item.title: 75% of Americans think mental health issues are treated worse than physical illness, new survey says. Here’s why
item.description: The older the survey respondents, the more likely they were to think mental health issues are treated worse than physical ones.

item.title: Trump and Hope Hicks Meet Again as She Testifies in Hush-Money Trial
item.description: Hope Hicks, once a spokeswoman for Donald J. Trump, broke down in tears on the witness stand as she talked about their time together.

item.title: How Does the World See the U.S. Campus Protests?
item.description: Abroad, some have praised the demonstrations. Others call the crackdowns evidence of American hypocrisy, or of a nation coming apart.

item.title: Right, wrong, and a moment for clarity: Why universities must adopt a zero-tolerance policy
item.description: The right to protest does not equal the right to cause the chaos roiling Columbia and other universities, writes Capitolis CEO Gil Mandelzis.
